meeting_annotations.transcript: I think combining things together can limit the design space too much, right? Usually, if you take two systems and combine them together, if they're not sort of well thought out, it's just kind of bad at both things, right? Um, the nice thing about having sort of multiple unit operations um in order related to one another is you can independently optimize and size each of them, right? Um, in many cases, you know, when you just to give you an example like the relative rates of each of those processes in sort of a multi-step system, ultimately the the slow step that will determine how fast the process goes. And so sometimes if let's say you can break out the slow step into a different reactor, just make that one way bigger, right? And then you can drive whatever process you need, but if it's all in the same reactor, you're kind of stuck at that slow step. You're right, Jordi, um, you know, there now you're making two reactors instead of one. Um, and there's different optimizations that can be done there, but um, you know, there's value in in doing that in terms of optimization.
